PRESIDENT fifth-straight trip to the playoffs, the longest since a 12-year FRONT OFFICE span from 1978 to 1987, and the fourth-straight season with 40Named team president on May 26, 2003, Billy King enters his or more wins.ninth season with the Philadelphia 76ers, marking his third sea-son as the president of the organization. King oversees all Before joining the 76ers, King served as an assistant coach foraspects of basketball operations, as well as all facets of business the Indiana Pacers under Larry Brown for four seasons. Heoperations. In Julythe 2001 NBA Finals. The 2002-03 season marked the 76ers 2000, he was honored as the Sports Executive of the Year at the Rainbow Sports Awards, reflecting not only his accomplish- ments in the sports industry, but also the grace, dignity, com- mitment and humanity that he exemplifies. In 2001, Street and Smith’s Business Journal named him one the industries \"Forty under 40.\" He was also inducted into Duke University’s Hall of Honor on Dec. 2, 2001, in its charter group. In May 2003, Sports Illustrated named King, along with fellow 76ers Sonny Hill and Allen Iverson, one of the “101 Most Influential Minorities in Sports,” a list that included “men and women that are reshaping the sports industry and opening doors through which others will follow.” King also was honored by the African-American Ethnic Sports Hall of Fame as the NBA Executive of the Year in July 2003. Born Jan. 23, 1966, King was a political science major at Duke and follows national and local politics closely. He is also a movie buff and previously hosted his own movie review show for WBNQ-Radio in Bloomington, Ill., titled \"Kings Clips.\" King resides in suburban Philadelphia with his wife, Melanie and Neopolitan Mastiff, Caesar. 25 ★ FRONT OFFICE ★ TONY DiLEOSR. He retired in 1993 as the league's all-time stealsCheeks the 21st head coach in team history on May 23, 2005. leader and was fifth on the career assists list. Maurice led the 76ers in assists in all 11 seasons he played in Philadelphia andCheeks arrives in Philadelphia after three-plus seasons as head also topped the team in steals in each of his first 10 years.coach of the Portland Trail Blazers. He recorded a mark of 162-139 (.538) in Portland, the fourth-highest win total in Blazers He was selected to the NBA's All-Defensive Team five timeshistory. During his time in Portland, the Blazers reached the (First Team: 1983, 1984, 1985, 1986; Second Team: 1987) andNBA Playoffs twice, and his 2002-03 squad tied for second in played in four All-Star games (1983, 1986, 1987, 1988). He wasthe Pacific Division with a 50-32 record. a member of 76ers 1983 World Championship team.He joined the Blazers on June 27, 2001, after serving seven sea- As an NBA player, Cheeks compiled career averages of 11.1 ppg,sons as an assistant coach for the 76ers. Cheeks worked under 6.7 apg and 2.1 spg in 1.101 games over 15 seasons whilehead coaches John Lucas (1994-96), Johnny Davis (1996-97), shooting .523 from the field and .793 from the free throw line.and Larry Brown (1997-2001). In 2000-01 under Brown,Cheeks helped guide the 76ers to a record of 56-26 (.683) and The 1978 West Texas State (currently West Texas A&M) grad-a spot in the NBA Finals. uate was a four-year starter and three-time MVP in college. He finished his collegiate career third on the Buffs' all-time scoring list, averaging 16.8 points per game and shooting 56.8 percent from the field as a senior. Cheeks was selected in the second round of the 1978 NBA Draft (36th overall) by the Sixers. A native of Chicago, he began his coaching career with the Quad City Thunder of the CBA. In his only season with Quad City, Cheeks helped guide the club to the CBA Championship. He then served as an assistant coach with the Sixers for seven seasons. A favorite in Philadelphia, Cheeks is one of seven for- mer Sixers players to have his number retired by the club (No. 10). Prior to joining the NBA ranks,Johnson served as an assistant athletic trainer for the NFL’sIndianapolis Colts. 30 ★ FRONT OFFICE ★ ALLEN LUMPKINDIRECTOR OF BASKETBALL ADMINISTRATION A fixture with the 76ers His outstanding work is not limited to the basketball court. for more than 28 years, In 1998, he was honored in the field of sports by the Alpha Allen Lumpkin enters his Kappa Alpha Sorority, Inc. at its annual “A Salute to first season as the director African-American Men” banquet, an honor that recognizes of basketball administra- outstanding achievement, leadership, dedication and com- tion after spending the mitment to the field of sports and community service. last seven seasons as the director of travel and team Lumpkin and his family reside in South Jersey. services. He was promot- ed to his current position FRONT OFFICE during the summer of 2005. In this role, Lumpkin isresponsible for team travel during the preseason and regularseason, as well as for summer league games. He alsoschedules all preseason games for the 76ers and acts as theteam’s liaison with all visiting teams during the season.“Lump,” as he is most commonly referred to, began work-ing for the Sixers as a ball-boy in 1977. After the 76ers wonthe NBA championship in 1983, he began working in thebox office and was later named the team’s equipment man-ager in 1988.SCOTT REGOEQUIPMENT MANAGER Scott Rego enters his sev- Rego served as the head equipment manager for the 2002 enth season as Equipment NBA All-Star Weekend when Philadelphia hosted the 2002 Manager. No stranger to NBA All-Star Game. Nicknamed “Soprano” by the players, the Philadelphia 76ers the Philadelphia native graduated from Temple University in organization, Rego began 1994 with a bachelor of arts degree. working for the Sixers as a ball-boy in 1988 and was Rego was born and raised in South Philadelphia, and cur- named Assistant Equip- rently resides in South Jersey with his family. ment Manager in 1996. He was promoted to his current position during the summer of 2000. As equipment manager,Rego is responsible for the ordering, daily maintenance andsupervision of all player equipment and uniforms at all ofthe team’s practices and games, both home and away. Regoalso maintains the Sixers locker room at the WachoviaCenter as well as the Sixers practice facility. In addition, hesupervises the Sixers ball-boys at all home games. 31
